div1.head: Jim to Mon. Paul Rockwell July 16th 1915
div1.p: Got your postal a couple of days ago but have looked in vain for the letter. Guess you’re quite occupied with Jeanne & Kiffin. Hope things are going well anyway.

One of our fellows is leaving to morrow for the States and I’m sending in this letter by him. By the way why don’t you put your Sun man onto the fact so a New York reporter at the dock can get some copy from him when he lands. He will sail on the French line in about a week. He’s well supplied with pictures and has been in the service for nine months. His name is Leif Barclay. The publicity you gave me has the notoriety for Lydia Pinkum’s Pink Pills looking like the announcement of a chamber- maids wedding. It branched out from New York papers until it got to the obscure recesses of Moore County, North Carolina. They went em [sic] all one better and I’m sure that when I return there will be a welcoming committee composed of the leading citizens in high hats, the fire department in red shirts and little girls in white dresses waving palm leaves.

By the way I have some good news. Remember my telling you I was asked to
write a sketch of the life of this section and that I turned in 7,000 words? Well our inspector, Mr. Andrew liked it so well that he has been reading it all over Paris. He was up here last night and told me that he read it to a group in which Mr. & Mrs[.] Bacon (Ex Ambassador outfit) and a couple of other high brows. Result: Mrs. Bacon, who is returning to America to get more money for the hospital is going to take the screed with her; get Teddy Roosevelt to write a preface and have it run in Scribners or Metropolitan. Andrew, who at one time was Assistant Sec’y of the Treasury is a side kick of Teddy’s and has also written to the Colonel. Some class if it frames up along the lines they’ve cooked up, eh [sic] what, old pal?

The enemy has been active of late in our secteur and we’ve all been working very hard. They haven’t been able to do anything since their success the night of July 4th. In that attack, preceded by a ten days shelling, they took back all we had gained since the month of January in the area known as the Quart en Reserve. About two kilometers at a certain point. We had to move our artillery back. They got to within 300 meters of a battery of 220 s. Of course a number of 75 s in the woods fell into their hands as well as 1,000 prisoners.
Don’t let on I told you this. Might get back and get me into trouble. We are now retaking the lost ground daily, tho [sic] it isn’t figured by trenches any more. There are no trenches left - just upheaved earth and bits of murdered nature. Seems hard to realize the damn swine are so close, but they are mighty near at some points. A little over a month ago I was in the first line at Le Col de Cygne and now that’s Boche. Oh well we’ll shove em [sic] back. On les ora. This small attack business means nothing but part of a process: the wearing down and killing of Germans. The big events will have to wait until next spring when Russia is supplied and has her new Armies ready and England can lend a hand. The Russian retreats now are all in our favor. The Germans are being worn down. I wouldn’t be surprised to have them meet with a disaster similar to that experienced by Napoleon this winter. Anyway it keeps them from making any big drives our way.

I’m anxious to hear all about you and your plans for I want to request a six day leave within the next two months and of course when I take the rest will depend on your schedule.
I have been given to understand that we will be allowed a leave. Each taking his turn in Paris. The soldiers here are getting six days clear. That is a full six at home. I’ve got two friends going all the way to Algeria. The time taken in traveling doesn’t count against them.

Nearly all the infantry here now is Colonial. Most of the men came from the Midi and it takes a man with a better knowledge of French then I have to understand them. Being for Bien and all that sort of patois. A number are seeing their first time at the front. They aren’t on to grenades and things and get hurt using them. Last night I brought down a man who had blown his hand off with one and I also transported four of his mates who had been wounded by the same grenade.
Haven’t heard from Marcelle Guerin in a long time. Hope she’s well. How’s your brother now? Wish him luck for me.
Well old “Compin” here’s how, and hoping to hear from you soon.
